commit.title: [loadpath] Move loadpath handling to the document layer.
commit.message:
[loadpath] Move loadpath handling to the document layer.

This is in fact an extension of the original approach of
using a flag that https://github.com/coq/coq/pull/9808 had.

The need to control library resolution in the upper layers first arose
when implementing jsCoq
(see for example https://github.com/ejgallego/jscoq/issues/45) and it
has become clearer over time than it would be very convenient to allow
the document manager to make decisions on which file to load.

For now we place the require logic at the vernac level, however we may
want to push it upwards, fully to the STM.

As a first step, we start to implement a large (and overdue)
refactoring of `Mltop` vs `Loadpath`. The main remaining task problem
to handle is how to handle the callback from the `Add LoadPath`
vernacular. Maybe it should be forbidden at the vernac level, becoming
a toplevel / STM only command?

For now we keep the logic for OCaml plugins in the `Mltop` modules,
this should likely be rewritten using `findlib` as to solve
https://github.com/coq/coq/issues/7698

TODO:

- keep in mind that the loadpath logic should end up being shared with
  coqdep to some extent.

For now we keep the logic for OCaml plugins in the `Mltop` modules,
this should likely be rewritten using `findlib` as to solve
https://github.com/coq/coq/issues/7698

TODO:

- keep in mind that the loadpath logic should end up being shared with
  coqdep to some extent.

commit.title: [loadpath] Move loadpath handling to the document layer.
commit.message:
[loadpath] Move loadpath handling to the document layer.

This is in fact an extension of the original approach of
using a flag that https://github.com/coq/coq/pull/9808 had.

The need to control library resolution in the upper layers first arose
when implementing jsCoq
(see for example https://github.com/ejgallego/jscoq/issues/45) and it
has become clearer over time than it would be very convenient to allow
the document manager to make decisions on which file to load.

For now we place the require logic at the vernac level, however we may
want to push it upwards, fully to the STM.

As a first step, we start to implement a large (and overdue)
refactoring of `Mltop` vs `Loadpath`. The main remaining task problem
to handle is how to handle the callback from the `Add LoadPath`
vernacular. Maybe it should be forbidden at the vernac level, becoming
a toplevel / STM only command?

For now we keep the logic for OCaml plugins in the `Mltop` modules,
this should likely be rewritten using `findlib` as to solve
https://github.com/coq/coq/issues/7698

TODO:

- keep in mind that the loadpath logic should end up being shared with
  coqdep to some extent.

want to push it upwards, fully to the STM.

As a first step, we start to implement a large (and overdue)
refactoring of `Mltop` vs `Loadpath`. The main remaining task problem
to handle is how to handle the callback from the `Add LoadPath`
vernacular. Maybe it should be forbidden at the vernac level, becoming
a toplevel / STM only command?

For now we keep the logic for OCaml plugins in the `Mltop` modules,
this should likely be rewritten using `findlib` as to solve
https://github.com/coq/coq/issues/7698

TODO:

- keep in mind that the loadpath logic should end up being shared with
  coqdep to some extent.

commit.title: [loadpath] Move loadpath handling to the document layer.
commit.message:
[loadpath] Move loadpath handling to the document layer.

This is in fact an extension of the original approach of
using a flag that https://github.com/coq/coq/pull/9808 had.

The need to control library resolution in the upper layers first arose
when implementing jsCoq
(see for example https://github.com/ejgallego/jscoq/issues/45) and it
has become clearer over time than it would be very convenient to allow
the document manager to make decisions on which file to load.

For now we place the require logic at the vernac level, however we may
want to push it upwards, fully to the STM.

As a first step, we start to implement a large (and overdue)
refactoring of `Mltop` vs `Loadpath`. The main remaining task problem

vernacular. Maybe it should be forbidden at the vernac level, becoming
a toplevel / STM only command?

For now we keep the logic for OCaml plugins in the `Mltop` modules,
this should likely be rewritten using `findlib` as to solve
https://github.com/coq/coq/issues/7698

TODO:

- keep in mind that the loadpath logic should end up being shared with
  coqdep to some extent.
